dt: {bc}lacking sharpness or quickness of sensibility or intellect {bc}{sx|insensitive||}, {sx|stupid||}

dt.t: He is too {wi}obtuse{/wi} to take a hint.

dt: {bc}difficult to comprehend {bc}not clear or precise in thought or expression

dt.t: It is also, unfortunately, ill-written, and at times {wi}obtuse{/wi} and often trivial.

pt: {sc}dull{/sc} {sc}blunt{/sc} {sc}obtuse{/sc} mean not sharp, keen, or acute. {sc}dull{/sc} suggests a lack or loss of keenness, zest, or pungency.
{sc}blunt{/sc} suggests an inherent lack of sharpness or quickness of feeling or perception.
{sc}obtuse{/sc} implies such bluntness as makes one insensitive in perception or imagination.

quotes.t: In fact, he was too {qword}obtuse{/qword} even to realize that his assignment to Tejas was a demotion …
Murdoch's art, like all good art, is highly structured and controlled—a house neat and clean enough to satisfy the most morally {qword}obtuse{/qword} of her upper-class British characters.
Only the most {qword}obtuse{/qword} missed the main message: humans risked so distorting the natural order that they were sentencing themselves to be destroyed by frost or furnace.

… either he, and the other people in his shop, and two people I subsequently ask are incapable of giving directions, or I am too rattled and {qword}obtuse{/qword} to follow them, but I cannot find the police station.

et: Middle English, from Latin {it}obtusus{/it} blunt, dull, from past participle of {it}obtundere{/it} to beat against, blunt, from {it}ob-{/it} against + {it}tundere{/it} to beat {ma}{mat|ob-|}, {mat|contusion|}{/ma}
shortdef: exceeding 90 degrees but less than 180 degrees
